Question: How do you properly prepare a steak.

(B) Take the steak out of cold storage and let come to room temperature, generously add salt and pepper to both sides and let sit for 10 minutes.

Question: Melt mini marshmallows.
Choices: (A) Place mini marshmallows in a microwave safe bowl and place in microwave; cook in 60 second intervals, stirring each time, until they are melted. (B) Place mini marshmallows in a microwave safe bowl and place in microwave; cook in 30 second intervals, stirring each time, until they are melted.

This answer is more plausible because melting mini marshmallows in the microwave requires careful attention to prevent them from burning. Cooking in 60 second intervals and stirring each time allows for even melting and prevents overheating. Cooking in 30 second intervals may not be enough time for the marshmallows to fully melt and could result in uneven melting or burning.
Cooking in 30-second intervals allows for better control over the melting process and prevents the marshmallows from overheating or burning.

Q: How to make the front of your DIY Viking Cardboard shield?
O: (A) Take a strip of paper then place a thumbtack in the end of your cardboard. Trace the desired length with a pencil. Cut out with scissors carefully. Question: Prevent baby from dropping sippy cup.
Choices: (A) Use dental floss to tie bottle to cart seat. (B) Use rope to tie bottle to cart seat.

Using dental floss or rope to tie the bottle to the cart seat is not a safe or practical solution as it can pose a choking hazard and may not secure the cup properly. A sippy cup strap or tether is a safer and more effective option as it is designed specifically for this purpose and can be easily attached to the stroller or high chair. This will prevent the cup from falling and reduce the risk of spills and accidents.
Dental floss is thinner and less likely to cause any harm or discomfort to the baby, while still being strong enough to hold the sippy cup in place.

Question: how to thread a needle
Choices: (A) Flatten the thread end and  wrap around your hand, tightly between two fingers, leaving about 1/4 inch sticking out. With your other hand, guide the eye of the needle over the thread end. (B) Flatten the thread end and pinch it tightly between two fingers, leaving about 1/4 inch sticking out. With your other hand, guide the eye of the needle over the thread end.

This method is more plausible because wrapping the thread around your hand helps to keep it taut and prevents it from slipping out of your fingers. Q: To quickly peel tomato skins off of tomatoes,
O: (A) bring a pot of water to a rolling boil on the stove top.  Drop a ripe tomato into ice water to blanch it.  When the skin starts to split at the top of the tomato, pull the tomato out and put it into the pot of boiling water.  Use your hands to peel the skin off. (B) bring a pot of water to a rolling boil on the stove top.  Drop a ripe tomato into the boiling water to blanch it.  When the skin starts to split at the top of the tomato, pull the tomato out and put it into a bowl of ice water.  Use your hands to peel the skin off.
